title: Release v1.0.0
body: Inspired by a conversation with @Dekkonot, I did some clean up work today and decided to finally cut a 1.0.0 release for `irc`. This library has been battle-tested for a long time at this point, and it's unlikely that I will meaningfully change the API going forward (which was the main reason we were still holding on to that `0.x.x` status). If the API is forced to change because of tokio in the future, so be it, but hopefully we can maintain compatibility going forward (especially in light of the fact that this library really is under passive maintenance at this point since I am not using IRC for anything in my day-to-day life anymore).

title: README, Getting Started: Update 0.13 to 0.15 in example
CertFP: The file must be a PKCS #12 archive
body:
While this archive is indeed DER-formatted, in contrast to `cert_path`, a regular DER file created from some certificate/key PEM file won't work:

```
openssl x509 -outform der -in foo.pem -out foo.der
```

This will result in the following OpenSSL error through tls-native error:

```
error:068000A8:asn1 encoding routines:asn1_check_tlen:wrong tag:crypto/asn1/tasn_dec.c:1188:
error:0688010A:asn1 encoding routines:asn1_d2i_ex_primitive:nested asn1
error:crypto/asn1/tasn_dec.c:752:
error:0688010A:asn1 encoding routines:asn1_template_noexp_d2i:nested asn1
error:crypto/asn1/tasn_dec.c:685:Field=version, Type=PKCS12
```

Instead, a PKCS #12 archive must be created like so:

```
openssl pkcs12 -export -out foo.p12 -inkey fookey.pem -in foocert.pem
```

If the PEM file contains both the private key and the certificate, the same file can be passed to `openssl` twice.

Also compare the documentation for `from_pkcs12` to `from_der` in native-tls, as used in the `new_secured_transport` function:

https://docs.rs/native-tls/0.2.11/native_tls/struct.Identity.html#method.from_pkcs12

title: Provide encapsulated Tls error information
body:
When `.to_string()` is invoked on a the crate-wide Error enum, the error message using #[error("...")] is displayed. Some of those wrapped internal enums also contain, possibly more helpful, error messages.  This will include the string gathered by `.to_string()` from the encapsulated enum in the main error message.

See also
https://github.com/squidowl/halloy/pull/143

title: irc-proto: allow modes with no prefix
body:
irc clients can query the details of some modes (e.g. request list of banned users) by sending a message with no plus or minus prefix, e.g. "MODE #chan b"

Not sure why this hadn't bitten me earlier, but now apparently the Framed tokio codec stream I'm reading stops processing data on first error so even if I could just ignore this it effectively disconnects my client, making channels rather painful.

Happy to rename NoPrefix to something else, from what I could see it's a query so Query? But Plus and Minus are rather litteral and not Add / Remove so NoPrefix is probably just as good.

Thanks!

title: Bump dependencies, set rust-version, and some more maintenance work
body:
Reason for this change is that I noticed that the `irc` crate was the sole cause in my dependency graph for pulling in some old dependencies (`parking_lot` among others). Some dependencies had CVEs specified for versions which were inside of their minimal ranges. So I went ahead and ran a `cargo upgrade --workspace` here.

I used a tool which tried to build and detect the MSRV and updated rust-version. It also sorted the fields, as they are specified in the Cargo documentation. Hope this i OK, otherwise I'll pull it back.

Since [features need to be additive](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/features.html#feature-unification), I've made it so that if both `tls-rust` and `tls-native` are activated, only `tls-rust` will be used. If you want this flipped, please tell me.

Finally I've added a Github workflow file, which performs most checks (including testing for MSRV). But I haven't ported any integration tests yet. So if you want to keep running them on Travis that is OK by me. [You can see the run here](https://github.com/udoprog/irc/actions).

title: Fix to allow stripping of 0-prefixed color codes
body: In the wild, many color codes seem to be often double digit, even if the number is < 10. This small change seems to fix it good enough.

title: Reconfigure chrono to remove CVE-2020-26235/RUSTSEC-2020-0159
body: This is similiar to #238 but instead reconfigures chrono to not use time 0.1

title: remove reference to for_each_incoming
body: from what i could see for_each_incoming nolonger exist this removes a leftover reference

title: Update the readme example
body: The readme example hasn't kept pace with the [API chage](https://github.com/aatxe/irc/blob/develop/src/client/data/config.rs#L147).  Also, I find it helpful to include the deps required by the example.

title: New option: dangerously_accept_invalid_certs
body:
This patch adds an option to dangerously ignore all ceritificate verifications. This option must be used with extreme caution and should only be used as a last resort.

Closes #209, #230

Co-authored-by: Hyeon Kim <simnalamburt@gmail.com>

CC @quite

title: Fix all `cargo clippy` warnings.
body: This PR doesn't change this library's behavior. It only fixes linter warnings.

title: Update broken link location to rfc 2812
body: Fix link rot.

title: Fix stringification of command suffixes with a leading colon
body:
Hello,

  irc-proto tries to canonicalize command suffixes by only inserting a leading colon when required.

  However, it fails to do so in one corner case (when the suffix itself starts with a colon), causing the leading colon to be gobbled up.
This fixes the corner case.

Cheers,

title: Fix docstring and README example for ping timeout default
body:
Hey,

I just noticed that you changed the default for ping_timeout from 10 to 20 in https://github.com/aatxe/irc/commit/e9d18b7f48f1aa6e50195be3f7ff8872ba6a410a but did not modify the docstring.
Here's a tiny fix :)

title: better errors for missing certificates
body:
Resolves #212.

This introduces a new `ConfigError` variant for when the configuration contains a path but the respective file cannot be read (could be because the file is missing or because of permission problems). This new variant is then used if a specified certificate file (server or client certificate) cannot be read.

To not duplicate code, I changed the visibility of `Config::path` to `pub(crate)` so it can be reused in the variants of `Connection::new_secured_transport`.

Not sure if or how to add tests for this.

title: Upgrade to Tokio 1.0
body:
I've had to pull in `pin-project`, because types like `Sleep` no longer implements `Unpin`. Meaning we should perform sound projections to use them somehow.

Other than that, there should be no major changes.

title: Enable 'futures-util/alloc' feature
body: `futures-util` requires its `alloc` feature to be enabled to use `SplitSink` and `SplitStream`, and since `default-features` is set to `false`, we need to enable it manually.

title: irc-proto: allow empty mode
body:
irc clients can query what modes a channel has by sending an empty mode
command

Closes #217.

Thanks for the reminder -- I've tried adding some basic test as there were none for mode, is that ok? Probably could add a bit more but it's a start.

title: Disable Pinger until after MOTD
body:
Some servers ignore PING commands until after login, so clients would
otherwise always time out, as mentioned in #207, #214, and #218.

With this change I am able to reliably connect to ircu servers.

title: Bump to Tokio 0.3.0 and clean up a few dependencies
body:
Not a ton of changes this release. Definitely not as many as `0.2` 🎉 

Removed dependencies:
* `futures-channel`
* `pin-utils` - seems to no longer used, and tokio comes with [tokio::pin](https://docs.rs/tokio/0/tokio/macro.pin.html) now.

title: Bump tokio-rustls, tokio-socks, webpki-roots, parking_lot
body: Subj (all of these are backward compatible for irc)

title: feat: add multi lines support for CTCP
body:
I tried to replace some `send_privmsg` into `send_ctcp` on a personal project... And it breaks everything :/ !

This PR simply add a multi lines support for `send_ctcp` as it is already implemented for `send_privmsg`.

title: Release 0.14!
body:
Fixes #205 and #193 by releasing irc and irc-proto 0.14!
It's a big release with us coming up to tokio 0.2.

title: feature: add rustls support
body:
Continuity of https://github.com/aatxe/irc/pull/151

- Rename SSL as TLS
- Set TLS as a feature:
-- Provide 2 TLS backends via features: `tls-native` and `tls-rust`.
- Does not expose `use_tls` from `config.rs` if TLS is disabled:
-- We should prefer a compile error instead of a fake `config.use_tls()` which always return false. Another alternative may be to put an `unimplemented!()` macro.

title: feature: Proxy Support
body:
Add a simple SOCKS5 proxy support with [tokio-socks](https://crates.io/crates/tokio-socks).

We must enable the `proxy` feature:
```rust
let config = Config {
    ...
    proxy_type: Some(ProxyType::Socks5),
    proxy_server: Some("127.0.0.1".to_owned()),
    proxy_port: Some(1080),
    ..Default::default()
};
```

Also, set `use_ssl` to `true` by default - avoiding MTIM attacks because of misconfigurations.

title: Handle suffix as a plain param
body: This replaces the internal handling of suffix and treats it as "just another param". Thankfully, this lets us clean up command parsing because we don't need to handle suffix vs params separately for every single command.

title: Fix client::test::no_user_tracking
body: Small fix for a failing test.

title: Upgrade bytes to match irc-proto
body: This means there's no more bytes mis-match between irc and irc-proto/tokio. I'm looking into other packages as well.

title: Properly declare required tokio-util features
body: Fixes #194

title: Make serde and toml optional
body: This is an experimental PR meant to drop serde/toml if they are disabled in the features. Unfortunately, this means renaming features (if we want them consistent) because the feature name toml cannot be used (as there's a package with the same name).

title: Escape and unescape IRCv3 message tag values
body: The escape sequences are described in the [IRCv3 Message Tags spec](https://ircv3.net/specs/extensions/message-tags#escaping-values).

title: Avoid synchronously resolving server address
body: `std::net::ToSocketAddrs::to_socket_address` might block the async function while the server address is being resolved, we instead return an impl of tokio's async plumbing for it and provide it directly to `TcpStream::connect`.

title: Fix updating outgoing client state
body: This also allows us to simplify the channel_tracking_names_part test.

title: Fix test which requires driving the outgoing queue
body: As per the comment in #184

title: Simplify Config structure
body:
This simplifies some of the `Config` structure, in particular this
means:

Parameters which are meaningfully equivalent longer stored in an `Option<T>`, an example of this is `channels`. If you don't want to join any channels you simply leave it as empty instead. In effect, `None` is behaviorally equivalent to `vec![]`.

We don't allocate when accessing certain configuration options. For example, when accessing `channels` we used to allocate a vector to handle the "empty case", we simply return the slice corresponding to the list of channels instead.

We skip serializing empty or optional configuration fields. From a deserialization perspective this is already something that was mostly supported through use of `Option<T>` and `#[serde(default)]`.

title: Switch to modern error handling
body:
This switches error handling from `failure` to `std::error::Error`, supported by [`thiserror`](https://docs.rs/thiserror).

The new equivalent of `failure::Error` is `anyhow::Error`, so we use this for tests.

title: First stab at bumping the project to tokio 0.2
body:
Sorry, this is a big change. But that's kinda expected :/

Related #182 

Non-exhaustive list of changes:
* Bumped edition to 2018.
* Dropped the use of `ClientExt` in favor if tiny bit of duplication in `ClientState` and macros.
* Removed `Client` trait and renamed `IrcClient` to `Client`.
* `PackedIrcClient` no longer exists.
* Renamed `error::IrcError` to `error::Error`.
* Removed all things associated with the reactor.
* `ClientStream` drives the stream for outgoing messages by default, unless it has been taken from the `Client` through `Client::outgoing`.
* You can access a thread-safe sender through `Client::sender`, which uses the outgoing queue for sending messages.
* Switched mutexes and locks to use [`parking_lot`](https://github.com/Amanieu/parking_lot).
* Updated all examples to use `#[tokio::main]` and tests to use `#[tokio::test]`.

#### TODO
* Commented out a test, since it requires more complex interaction than what is currently usable.
* ~~Commented out configuration tests since I couldn't run them locally (Windows dev environment).~~
* Burst-based rate limiter has not been ported yet.

title: Fix compilation errors on 0.14
body:
- Type can not be safely sent across threads (src/client/reactor.rs:141)
- Unhandled Result  (src/client/reactor.rs:144)
- Expected value, found reference (src/bin/build-bot.rs:21)

title: Don't send an empty CTCP SOURCE response
body:
Noticed this while asking a url-bot-rs instance for it's `SOURCE`.

```
-- CTCP query to u: SOURCE
-- CTCP reply from u: SOURCE https://github.com/nuxeh/url-bot-rs
-- CTCP reply from u: SOURCE
```

title: Mark Future in PackedIrcClient as Send + 'static
body: This makes it feasible to use with Tokio Runtime.

title: spawn handler futures on the reactor
body: Right now handler calls are done entirely sequentially. This defeats the purpose of async since one handler that has a long running async operation (say a network call) will prevent other messages from being processed. This PR spawns the handler futures on the reactor so that they don't block the execution of futher handlers.

title: Handle the case of a single SOH in PRIVMSG
body: Fix for #170

title: parse traditional USER form
body:
Fixes: #160.

Not sure where the tests should go; couldn't really find any tests for parsing like this?

title: Add test bot for CI
body:
Fixes #142 

@aatxe I have put this in `src/bin` as I wasn't too sure on the best way to approach this. Obviously the bot doesn't want to be part of the normal tests as it should only run during a CI build, that seems to leave `src/examples` and `src/bin` as the two possible places to put this. 

Out of the two the bin folder seemed most appropriate as it separates this out from the examples and allows us to run the bot as an individual component during the CI process.

I would really appreciate any feedback on this as I am pretty new to Rust 🙂🦀

title: Add 'Send' bound for PackedClient client future.
body:
The Future is Send anyway, but this bound on the Box is neccessary
to use the future across threads because the compiler can't figure
out the Send bound otherwise.

title: Refactor IrcClientFuture and ConnectionFuture to own the config
body:
This refactors IrcClientFuture and ConnectionFuture to own
the config instead of holding a reference.

This is unfortunately a breaking change. 
I didn't see a way to keep the old public API without the reference.

This is required though for dynamically connecting to additional servers on the same reactor.

The `examples/multiserver.rs` example only works because the `Config` structs are in the same scope that `Reactor::run()` is called, which is not possible in a dynamic (future) context, where you need to use `Handle::spawn` to initiate a new client.

title: Finalize 0.13.6.
body: This fixes bugs in the color stripping code and otherwise updates dependencies.

title: Add a link to url-bot-rs
body: Add a link to url-bot-rs, a project making use of this crate, to the readme.

title: Introduces Prefix enum
body:
Hey, this is my first rust PR.  Very open to making any changes.

Ref [#143 Parsing message prefixes (sources) into an enumeration](https://github.com/aatxe/irc/issues/143)

---

There's an issue in that both of the following are allowed by the types, but there's only one string representation for both of them. The parser never produces this (gives the second), so it'd just be manual enum construction.

```rust
Nickname("nick".into(), None, Some("host".into()))
Nickname("nick".into(), Some(String::new()), Some("host".into()))
```

This is harmless until you try to do...

```
let prefix = Prefix::Nickname("nick".into(), None, Some("host".into()));
let s = format!("{}", prefix);
assert_eq(prefix, s.parse.unwrap()); // panics
```

---

I'm not sure what this function should be named, but it seems weird doing `string.parse().unwrap()` everywhere, since it's not apparent at the call site that it never fails.

```rust
impl Prefix {
   pub fn new_from_str(s: &str) -> Prefix {
```

Edit: not sure which branch this should be based on.

title: Upgrade native-tls and tokio-tls to 0.2
body:
This should fix builds for systems with OpenSSL 1.1.1.

[OpenSSL Issue](https://github.com/sfackler/rust-openssl/issues/994)
